keyTakeAways: The Louvre Museum in Paris was the site of a major theft involving nine historically significant artifacts, including jewelry once gifted by Napoleon to his wife Marie-Louise and pieces belonging to Empress Eugénie.
The stolen items include a sapphire diadem, emerald necklace, reliquary brooch, and a diamond bow brooch, all of which have deep historical and cultural significance to French history.
The heist was described as a 'national disaster' by art recovery expert Arthur Brand, emphasizing the profound loss to French national heritage.
One item, Empress Eugénie's crown, was recovered near the scene but was damaged during the theft, indicating the severity of the crime.
The stolen jewelry, especially the emerald necklace and diadem, was historically passed through royal families and private collectors, with some pieces having been sold or altered over time.
The recovered crown contains 1,354 diamonds and 56 emeralds, and it was originally crafted for Empress Eugénie in 1855.
The sapphire diadem features 24 Ceylon sapphires and 1,083 diamonds and was part of the Orléans family collection until it was acquired by the Louvre in 1985.
The emerald necklace gifted by Napoleon to Marie-Louise was preserved and sold to the Louvre in 2004 for 3.7 million euros, underscoring its value and historical importance.
The reliquary brooch contains the 17th and 18th Mazarin diamonds, which were given to Louis XIV by Cardinal Mazarin in 1661, linking the item to France’s royal lineage and early monarchy.

The diamond bow brooch originated from a belt exhibited at the 1855 Universal Exhibition and was later transformed into a brooch by Empress Eugénie, later purchased by New York socialite Caroline Astor in 1887 and returned to the Louvre in 2008 for 6.72 million euros.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A major theft occurred at the Louvre Museum in Paris on Sunday, October 20, 2025, when four thieves stole nine historically significant artifacts from the Apollo Gallery in just seven minutes. Among the stolen items are a sapphire diadem, an emerald necklace gifted by Napoleon to Marie-Louise, and several pieces associated with Empress Eugénie, including a reliquary brooch and a diamond bow brooch. The items are of immense cultural and historical value, linked to French royalty and crafted by notable jeweler artisans. One of the items, Eugénie’s crown, was recovered near the scene but was damaged. Art recovery expert Arthur Brand described the heist as a 'national disaster' for France, warning that the thieves may melt down the gold and silver. The stolen jewelry has deep historical roots, passed through royal families and private collectors, and was valued at millions of euros. The incident underscores the vulnerability of cultural heritage and raises global concern about the protection of national treasures.
title: Historic jewels stolen in ‘national disaster’ for France: What we know about missing Louvre treasures
